messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:
> I don't know how a JVM typically works inside, but I don't see how you can
> get to this conclusion from your example. I'd rather conclude that the class
> file is not was is meant by "class definition" in this case. It's probably
> more like an internal representation of the class inside the JVM after the
> class file got loaded.
>

I am sure there is a perfectly reasonable "justification" for why a
ClassDefNotFoundError makes sense. But it is misleading.


If a class is not found, the class loader will throw a
ClassNotFoundException. If something goes wrong during static
initialization, the VM throws an ExceptionInInitializerException.
Subsequent attempts to reference the class result in
NoClassDefFoundError. For some reason, the Error rarely has an error
message that makes any sense.

We see it all the time in code like this :

static {
FileReader reader = new FileReader("my.properties");
......
}


It is very confusing to get a NoClassDefFoundError when the class is
cleary right there. It is also insidious because tool vendors and
framework providers have to load and run third party code (colloquially,
/user code/) and have to bullet proof their own code a little more than
usual. It's bad practice to catch Throwable, but if you don't it's
likely that Errors will leak out. We end up catching throwable and
rethrowing certain Errors.


I agree with you that Errors should represent unrecoverable system
errors. NoClassDefFoundError is not one of those. Neither is
OutOfMemoryError nor StackOverflowError.


In the OP's case, I would wager that a class really was not found and
that the ClassNotFoundException caused a static initializer to fail
which caused a ClassDefNotFoundError.

Kevin
